;Halfway through the long holiday, the Midi Music Festival held in Nanyang, Henan suddenly appeared on the social media hot search list, not because How well done, but because - "stealing things". For this city that was once famous for Zhuge Wolong, if the case cannot be solved as soon as possible, not only may the next Midi Music Festival be ruined, but it will also affect the reputation of the entire city.

;

;On October 3, the keywords "Midi steals things" quickly became hot topics on social media. According to information released by netizens at the scene, the music festival had ended the day before, and many music fans who participated in the music festival had not yet evacuated. However, a large number of nearby villagers went into the campground to search for things. According to Solitaire’s stolen property statistics, some people’s clothing and shoes were stolen, some wine and tea were stolen, some camping equipment such as tents, sleeping bags, and moisture-proof mats were lost, and high-value electronic and digital products such as computers, mobile phones, cameras, and recording equipment were stolen. Some "thiefs" only took away the tent, leaving other materials neatly in place. Even the fist-thick cables on the stage were stolen.

;

;According to self-reported information by the thieves, the total value of the stolen materials may reach hundreds of thousands of yuan. A video circulating on the Internet shows a middle-aged woman who was caught taking something out of her bag while defending herself: "We just went to get it when no one was there," as if the owner of the tent had temporarily left ( Maybe you go out to eat or even just use the toilet), the things in the tent become ownerless and can be taken as you please.

;

;As the first original music festival in China, the Midi Music Festival with a history of more than 20 years has become one of the most famous carnivals in the Chinese music industry, especially rock music. For the venue where the music festival is held, tens of thousands of enthusiastic music fans from all over the country will not only bring direct income to the local area, but also become an excellent opportunity to promote the local area. Therefore, many cities, especially third- and fourth-tier cities, are competing to hold or invite large-scale music festivals to be held locally.

;

;This Midi Music Festival was held in Nanyang and also received great attention from the local area. According to the official social media account "Nanyang Release" of the Nanyang Municipal Government Information Office, on September 29, the opening day of the Central Plains Midi Music Festival, the Secretary of the Nanyang Municipal Party Committee and the Mayor, wearing red volunteer uniforms, personally greeted the guests at the exit of Nanyang Railway Station. Music fans all over the country. Half a month ago, Nanyang City held a preparatory meeting for the Midi Music Festival. The Secretary of the Municipal Party Committee personally made arrangements and required the establishment of a high-standard headquarters at the municipal level to carefully carry out various guarantee work for the music festival.

;

;A few days before the opening of the music festival, the Nanyang Municipal Government Information Office also released a city image promotional video and a local "food, drink, and fun picture" through its official account to promote local tourism resources. Such high-standard preparation and reception highlight the importance attached to the music festival. It was with this kind of attention that the music festival itself seemed to go without any problems. However, what was unexpected was that large-scale thefts occurred after the festival. It can be said that the previous efforts were ruined. This makes the previous official statement of “protecting the personal and property safety of tourists” a joke.

;

;In addition to theft, netizens who attended the music festival accused some people of harassing tourists in the name of toasting during dinner in the hotel, and even beating tourists while drunk.

;

;This information spreads rapidly through social networks. If the local area fails to take prompt measures to identify problems such as theft and harassment, it will greatly damage the image of the local area. In addition to the stolen music fans who said that if there is no result in handling this incident, they will never visit Nanyang again. Some netizens also said that they felt very unsafe after watching the video of the villagers taking things away, and they will definitely do so when traveling in the future. Avoid this place.

;

;According to the descriptions of the thieves and live music fans, most of the thieves were local villagers, who even used tricycles to pull the items. This scene can't help but remind people of the situations that have happened in many places before where villagers stole the crops of foreign agricultural entrepreneurs. It was reported in the summer of 2019 that a sweet potato farmer in Henan contracted 200 acres of land to grow watermelons. When the watermelons matured, nearby villagers gathered in groups to steal the melons. A melon-picking incident also occurred in Jiaxing, Zhejiang, where almost all the watermelons from more than 20 greenhouses were stolen. Some melon thieves were even caught by melon farmers and fell to the ground and were "injured" during the pulling process. Instead, the melon farmers were asked to pay compensation.

;

;In these theft incidents, some places often use various excuses to excuse local farmers. For example, it is not "theft", but they believe the rumor that "the owner doesn't want it anymore", or there are people in the local area who are not the owners. The tradition of “picking up the leaks” after harvesting, etc. In the Midi Music Festival theft incident, some participants alleged that after catching the thief and calling the police, the police let the villagers go because "there was no evidence to prove the theft." If the property of participants cannot be protected for a large-scale event that the government attaches so much importance to, who will dare to come here in the future?

;

;It is true that the quality of villagers in some places is not high, they are greedy for petty gains, and their legal awareness is weak. They have the idea that the law does not punish the public, and they feel that taking some things from "outsiders" will not do anything. If local officials do not take severe measures to punish these thieving villagers and cannot effectively protect the interests of foreign tourists or investors, and their reputation is ruined, no one will dare to travel or invest here again.

;

;According to the announcement from the Midi Music Festival Organizing Committee, the local police have set up a task force to investigate the theft cases. Some fans also reported that some of the stolen items had been recovered. This time Nanyang must make every effort to solve the case, recover the stolen goods, reduce the losses of music fans, and at the same time severely punish the thieves without mercy. Only in this way can it be possible to restore the reputation, restore the music festival, restore the music fans, and restore the tourists from all over the country.

;One day in the summer of 2017, Yan Ge was vaccinating her one-month-old son at a clinic in Dublin when she suddenly received an email from Irish writer Lucy Caldwell. She was invited to contribute to Faber's short story collection Being Various: New Irish Short Stories ( "Short Story Collection";) Write a novel. Lucy is the editor of this collection. She had read two of Yan Gefa's stories in the "Irish Times" and found them interesting, so she came here.

;

;Yan Ge still remembers her shock at that time: first of all, she was an outsider, no one in the Irish literary world knew her, she had only published two novels in newspapers; secondly, she was the only one in Ireland. How did you become an Irish writer after living for a few years?

;

;In that email that made Yan Ge feel unreal, Lucy greatly broadened the concept of Irish writers - this concept should include writers who were born in Ireland but grew up elsewhere, and writers who were chosen from elsewhere. Writers who call Ireland home include those who somehow find themselves living in Ireland.

;

;What happened next unfolded smoothly. Yan Ge wrote a story that took place in Dublin, "How I Fell in Love with the Well-Documented Life of Alex Whelan", which was well received and included in this new collection of Irish short stories. The first article (;Published in 2019;). Later, Angus, the editor of "Different: A Collection of New Irish Short Stories" and director of Faber Publishing, learned that Yan Ge was writing a collection of short stories and approached his agent, Matt, hoping to She gave Faber exclusive preview rights.

;

;;

;

;Yan Ge visited Wangcong Temple in his hometown of Pi County when he was a child;(provided by interviewee/picture);

;

;Faber is a purely literary publishing organization founded in 1921. It has published the works of 13 Nobel Prize writers and 6 Booker Prize writers. There will be no sky-high royalties, and packaging and promotion will not cost as much as cutting-edge companies. If it is not given to Faber, the agent will submit the work to various publishing houses. If multiple publishing houses compete for the manuscript, it will be auctioned. As a result, the manuscript may be sold at a relatively high price.

;

;But Matt believes that Faber is suitable for Yan Ge’s work. It is of stable quality, responsible, and can be cooperated for a long time. Moreover, the editors of this book are Kazuo Ishiguro and Sebastian. Barry's managing editor.

;

;Finally Faber was given exclusive preview rights.

;

;The exclusive preview period generally does not exceed 10 days. Faber responded quickly. He sent the message on Friday and gave the quotation on Wednesday. After the two parties negotiated, it was determined on Thursday that he would buy the rights to two books, including the completed "Elsewhere" and another book scheduled to be delivered in 2024. The novel "Hotel Destination".

;

;"This means that the next five years are almost bought out." Yan Ge is worried that the second book is due to be delivered in April 2024 according to the contract, and because of the Chinese novel "Pingle County Chronicles" All work is behind schedule.

;

;The veteran American literary publisher Scribner will also acquire the copyright for Yan Ge’s collection of short stories and the 2024 novel. Scribner published works by Hemingway and Fitzgerald. It was later acquired by Simon & Schuster and became the company's flagship publishing house. It also published books by pure literary writers such as Annie Proulx. , and also publishes works by Stephen King, the master of horror novels.

;

;;

;

;

;In the summer of 2023, "Elsewhere" will be published in the UK and the United States. , winning praise from media outlets including The Irish Times, The Guardian, The New York Times and The New Yorker.

;

;In the summer of 2023, Yan Ge took her son and husband back to Chengdu after three years of COVID-19. To be precise, back to Pidu District (;Originally known as Pixian County;) - her hometown - the birthplace of her story of Pingle Town.

;

;;

;

;" We are here to oppose English”

;

;;Southern People Weekly:;;I will interview you in the summer of 2018 At that time, you were embarking on a creative writing project in the UK, published two novels in the "Irish Times", and had just completed one of Faber's "New Irish Novels". It was a year later that you got an agent. matter. What impressed me most is that you metaphorically joined the "Special Olympics" in the English literary world. Five years later, you have become an English writer signed with a first-class international literary publishing house. Do you still feel like a Paralympian? ;

;

;;Yan Ge: ;;I don’t feel that way anymore. English writing is a new career for me now, and I face many problems, but they are not so-called language problems, or language is the most superficial problem, and it may not even be considered a problem compared with other problems. English writing is a kind of artistic self-exploration for me. If I were an artist, my medium would be words. Now I am using a new way, new tools, new materials and media to make works. This new medium will bring a new change to my works. This is the most important thing. ;

;

;;Southern People Weekly:;;Remember the last interview, you were right I said there is nothing terrible about writing in English. The tone is exactly the same as now. Is there any substantial difference between the two? For example, five years ago you were more free to enjoy the freedom of expression that the new language brought to you. Now , after strict writing training in the English literary tradition, have you found some kind of certainty in your writing? ;

;

;;

;

;;Yan Ge:;;Definitely. During the process of studying and living in the UK, I read more and more things in depth, which must be related. I think these are also based on my culture. After all, I am a Chinese writer, so my literary system and narrative system are Chinese. Although I now understand more or less how the other system works, I feel that Chinese is still my language. The root of this is that, ultimately, the way of thinking about Chinese and Chinese literature is an anti-dualistic way. ;

;

;In the English-speaking world, the writing of minority writers like us is a kind of post-colonial cultural expression that must subvert the so-called orthodox English. This is why English as a This is a fate that postcolonial language must face.

;

;Irish writers are probably the first group of writers in the world to write in this post-colonial way, and they are also anti-English. After the British occupied Ireland, Irish became an illegal language. If you spoke Irish, you would be fined and arrested. My husband is Irish. As an intellectual and journalist, he always tells me that you can write in English however you want. We are here to oppose this language anyway.

;

;So when I returned to Ireland, I felt like I was returning to my second natal home. Dublin was the last stop for the promotion of my new English book. As a result, all the tickets for the sharing session were sold out, the venue was full, and there were people sitting on the windowsill. , I was very moved.

;

;;

;

;< strong>;Southern People Weekly:;;In that environment, no one will care about your language. ;

;

;;Yan Ge: ;;Yes, no one will think about this problem. It may have something to do with Irish culture. Everyone thinks this is a natural thing. The two stories I submitted to The Irish Times were published directly by the editor, which made me feel like I had landed in front of English readers. Originally, I was waiting for the editor to give me a lot of revision comments. Gradually, I learned that newspapers here have this tradition and are not very good at changing the author's manuscripts. Only magazines and books have an editorial process. ;

;

;;

;

;In the English writing circle, everyone reads and comments on each other's manuscripts

;

;;Southern People Weekly:;;When you first write in English, do you show it to your husband first? I remember when I interviewed Ha Jin in 2001, he said that when he first wrote a novel, he would check whether the words were authentic to his son who was born in the United States. At that time, he had just won the National Book Award in the United States. ;

;

;;Yan Ge: ;;Some of them will be read to him. My husband is my first reader. When I write Chinese, I will also translate it orally to him. share. But if it involves a subject with a Chinese cultural background, it will not be shown to him, but to people who do not understand Chinese culture at all. For example, there is an article "Hai" (Hai) in "Elsewhere", which is about Confucius and his disciples. It also alludes to the British political system. People without a Chinese cultural background will see a completely different connotation. I asked a historical novelist to read the manuscript, which was more than 20,000 words. She read it carefully and wrote a lot of feedback. ;

;

;In the English writing circle, one thing that I like very much is that everyone reads each other's manuscripts, devotes a lot of time and energy to each other's works, and also gives sharp opinions. . My agent was also one of my early readers. This atmosphere is particularly healthy. These people I trust allow me to be bolder and try more things and experiment with more languages ​​without looking forward or backward. It’s like I’m doing acrobatics in this language. Even if I fall down, there are still people. then.

;

;;Southern People Weekly:;;Chinese writers don’t do this. ;

;

;;Yan Ge: ;;Chinese literature talks about genius. I prefer the workshop tradition among British and American literary creative groups. Discussions and discussions give me the feeling of being in a community. A girlfriend of mine sent me a manuscript that she had revised 36 times and asked me to make further comments. Chinese writers would avoid doing this because it would cast doubt on their own genius. ;

;

;My soon-to-be-published Chinese novel "Pingle County Chronicles" is the product of many years of work behind closed doors. When I first finished it, I was very scared and didn't know how to write it. I sent it to "Harvest" When editing, I especially hope she can give me feedback. For example, for many ancient poems in the book, I asked the editor to find professionals to help review them. If no one comments, I'm like running around naked, which is terrible. I am probably used to the way Western creative writing groups operate, and I am afraid that others will not give me advice.

;

;;

;

;" The editor wanted me to delete the redundant convoluted parts."

;

;;Southern People Weekly:;;When writing in English, have you ever imagined what your readers are like? ;

;

;;Yan Ge: ;;When I write in Chinese, I can imagine my readers. I am not necessarily writing for them, but there is probably an implicit reference to the readers. concept. But when writing in English, I feel a sense of panic all the time - I can't imagine what the reader looks like. He is definitely not white, but I don't know who he is - he has no face and no identity. I wasn't a first or second generation immigrant either, just someone stuck there temporarily, and imaginary readers became one of my biggest problems. Then there is the feeling of doing an academic experiment. According to my own interests, if I get to this point today, I will write this, and if I get to that point tomorrow, I will write that. ;

;

;;Southern People Weekly:;;These are also the novels in "Elsewhere" What’s the reason for the different themes and very different writing techniques? ;

;

;;Yan Ge: ;;Yes. When I write in Chinese, I am very rooted - very grounded, so that I can absorb nutrients and feel at ease, but at the same time, it is also tied and fixed. English writing is rootless, very unstable, yet full of vitality and possibility. ;

;

;;Southern People Weekly:;;Now is your first English short story Now that the collection has been published, do you know who your readers are? ;

;

;;Yan Ge:;;I met various ethnic minority writers at reading events and book signings in the UK. They felt that my works It inspired them - they told me that someone like me wrote such a book in such a way, which moved them very much. There are people like this everywhere I go. They are very young, and many of them are ethnic minority authors who are studying creative writing. ;

;

;I am very happy, I found that I am writing for these people. We minority writers interact with each other and open up a new English writing space. I just give this The space adds some more possibilities. For example, the most superficial expression is that you can add Chinese to English novels.

;

;It is easy to fall into the trap of dualism when discussing "readers". Generally speaking, the English readers that come to mind must be the mainstream society dominated by white people. I think this idea is quite original and very 80s.

;

;;Southern People Weekly:;;Basically from your agent to your book editor Being white and male represents a certain center of power. Does your work being published by well-known established publishing houses in the UK and the United States mean that you are moving closer to a certain center? ;

;

;;Yan Ge: ;;As an ethnic minority writer, the English I write must be essentially against English (Against English). It’s not that I want to join the so-called English literature, but literature that is completed using English as the language (Literatures in English). My agent and editors are very supportive of my starting point. ;

;

;In the current context, if you think that people like me must knock on the door and enter a certain center, then it is essentially worship and submission to the Anglo-center.

;

;;Southern People Weekly:;;If you are not writing for white readers or do not want to enter the mainstream, In addition to challenging traditional English reading habits from a textual perspective—for example, by including some ancient Chinese poems or even Chinese characters—do you express your stance from other perspectives? ;

;

;;Yan Ge: ;;I will not exclude a certain group, nor will I particularly try to please a certain group. For example, there are local white people in my collection of novels, but there are also Chinese things, including Chinese characters, as well as the non-linear time structure of traditional Chinese literature, and even anti-simplification. But I also hope that every type of reader can enter my text and have his own understanding when he leaves. ;

;

;And the partial uninterpretability of the text is also part of my plan. Making certain paragraphs and details into something completely unfamiliar at first glance is also my expression. a part of. In fact, it’s a bit similar to how I write in Sichuan dialect. I don’t want to reject Mandarin readers when I write in Sichuan dialect. I just want to retain the characteristics of Sichuan dialect.

;

;;

;

;"Elsewhere"

;

;In the collection "Elsewhere", it is a bit like a mixture, with some traditional Western literary meanings novel, but also has Chinese logic and Chinese literary values. For example, in "Travel in the Summer" (;"travel in summer";), I want to express many things. Deliberately a little idle, this kind of technique is not allowed in English novels.

;

;I remember when I first published this story in a Canadian magazine, the editor thought the story was very good, but wanted me to delete the redundant convoluted parts. I felt a little embarrassed at that time. As a writer, I was very willing to accept other people's opinions, but in the end I wrote her a long email saying that this was an ancient Chinese story, so I hope This classical China is both in content and form. I said that the protagonist of this story is Shen Kuo, and his book wants to cover everything in the universe. This inclusiveness is also the focus of this story. I also talked about some background about implicitness and leisurely writing, and finally she was convinced by me.

;

;;Southern People Weekly:;;When it comes to Chinese writers who write in English, people will mention Ha Jin or Li Yiyun, their backgrounds are completely different from yours. They only started writing when they arrived in the United States. However, you were already a budding novelist before going abroad. Your works have been translated into more than a dozen languages. As a "second generation" of Chinese immigrant writers, ”, how do you view your identity? ;

;

;;

;

;From left to right are translator Natasha Bruce, Canadian novelist Madeleine Thien, Yan Ge's "Our Family" translator Nicky Harman, Yan Ge after the Times Literary Festival Group photo ;(provided by the interviewee/picture);

;

;;Yan Ge:;;It should be said that I am very Fortunately, because I have indeed written more and longer in Chinese literature, I always feel that Chinese is my home field, and I just come to the English world to play, so I am relatively confident. Why should I try to please white people? I feel like my work is more de-duality. If I were asked to write like a white person, I wouldn’t want to. It doesn’t make any sense to me and is a particularly ridiculous thing. ;

;

;Another fortunate thing is that Ha Jin and Li Yiyun have helped our generation of writers complete the exploration of themes and wrote many "Chinese stories". Our generation can no longer When writing in English, the subject matter can be broader and the form can be freer. I read Li Yiyun's first short story collection more than ten years ago when I first went abroad. At that time, I couldn't see how good it was. That book was actually not written for Chinese readers like me. Now her works have long gone out of the box at that time, becoming more and more open and better. To a certain extent, it is precisely because the kind of "Chinese stories" that the white mainstream society needed have been written before. Now she and many of us can get out of this stereotype and write stories related to China or It has nothing to do with it. If you write about the real or virtual world, the Middle Ages or the sci-fi future, you can be more creative in content and form.

;

;(Interview Assistant: Zhu Zhu.)
