;

;Wang Di at Heming Tea House in Chengdu People's Park;(Hua Xiaofeng/Photo);

;

;Public Space

;

;Historian Wang Di's "Teahouse: The Decline and Renaissance of Chengdu's Public Life 1950-2000" is in Chengdu Xing Bookstore held a new book sharing session. The founder of the bookstore, Zhang Feng, set up a traditional tea seat in front of the stage at the entrance of the bookstore: a table, three bamboo chairs, three bowls of tea, and a thermos. Zhang Feng, as the host, sits on the right. Sitting on the left is artist Wang Hai, who was Wang Di’s classmate at Chengdu No. 3 Middle School. Wang Di sat in the middle. When he didn't need to talk, he poured water for the two people around him from time to time. This made Zhang Feng feel embarrassed. Wang Di said: I am Dr. Tea.

;

;The night after the event, Wang Di and I chatted until more than 10 o'clock under the street lamp of Youxing Bookstore. Wang Di realized that it was very late and asked Zhang Feng who was waiting aside: "When will the bookstore be open?" Zhang Feng said: "It can stay open as long as we like."

;

;A few months Previously, before the COVID-19 epidemic was over, Zhang Feng and Lingzi, who was studying for a doctorate in anthropology at Cambridge University, hosted a sharing session by Wang Di at the Dunba Bar in the suburbs of Chengdu. There was no theme and they could talk about whatever they wanted. Wang Di spoke from 7:30 pm to 12:00 midnight. Lingzi paused the chat to let the more than 100 listeners sitting around take a break. Wang Di thought he was done. But Reiko told him that it was just halftime. Wang Di was going to fly to Macau the next morning. I thought he would say, it’s too late today, so let’s just stop here. Unexpectedly, he said, today I will lay down my life to accompany you. The activity lasted until about 1 o'clock in the morning. This is an amazing and vibrant atmosphere in Chengdu’s public space, and those who participate in it will lose track of time. This is the Decameron, but it is much more than the Decameron. I met Brother Feng in both Youxing Bookstore and Dunba. He seemed to be constantly posting about various activities in Chengdu’s public spaces. I admired his energy and he said it was nothing, it was very simple and it didn't take any time. I also met lawyer Zhang Ying again. She came to participate in Wang Di's sharing session. The "Bright Dialogue" she hosted is still running. She hopes that people can learn the awareness of thinking instead of just speaking. Skill.

;

;Now that Wang Di is back in Chengdu, he has been invited to many activities, almost all of which he talked about from morning till night. He was very patient with all kinds of questions, even though he had answered many similar questions many times. He has appeared in various media. He enjoys speaking to the public about his historical research and writing. His name is connected with "street culture", "pao brother" and "teahouse" in the main fields of his research. He is concerned about the relationship between people and space, communicating specific words and objects. He thinks about the significance of history to the present and is willing to spread his thoughts to a wider scope. He became one of the most popular historians. At the sharing meeting, Zhang Feng talked about the rising "public history" and called Wang Di "the historian in the teahouse." The background of their conversation was transparent. I could see behind the background board. Old aunties were sitting comfortably on bamboo chairs chatting. A courier guy wearing a helmet was walking with takeaways. People on motorcycles were walking by. Pass. This is a natural superposition of the lives of Chengdu citizens, forming a richly layered visual landscape.

;

;"Teahouse: The Decline and Revival of Public Life in Chengdu, 1950-2000" can be referred to as "Teahouse (;Part 2;)》. In "Teahouse (;Part 1;), also known as "Teahouse: Public Life and Microcosm of Chengdu 1900-1950", Wang Di I have compared teahouses in Sichuan and other places, such as teahouses in Guangdong. "Guangdong is generally called a teahouse. On the surface it looks like a teahouse in Sichuan, but it obviously serves the middle class and is different from the 'popular' teahouses in Sichuan." When describing Guangdong teahouses, Wang Di used the word "grand".

;

;In Macau, in order to intuitively compare with Sichuan teahouses, Wang Di took us to a Cantonese-style teahouse in the Grand Lisboa for morning tea. This teahouse is more like a fine restaurant, with far more dishes on the table than tea sets. The waiter brought us barbecued pork cakes and carrot cakes from a cart. There are already roast goose, shrimp dumplings, soup dumplings, siomai, beef brisket and fish soup on the table. This sumptuous morning tea costs more than a thousand patacas. The surrounding design is also very thoughtful. The wall decoration is designed with a steamer-like texture, giving people a feeling of steaming steam. Wang Di had been in such steaming heat.

;

;The turning point

;

;That day happened to be the time for the college entrance examination in the mainland, and schools in Macau began to have holidays. High school students in Macau do not need to take the college entrance examination. They all apply to go to university. Wang Di feels that children in the mainland are too involved now. "We like the imperial view of history, but we actually advocate being a superior person. We look down on ordinary people, so we hope that our children will not be ordinary people. Let every ordinary person live with dignity. This is what we should advocate. This is what I The reasons for emphasizing the civilian view of history."

;

;;;

;On September 17, 2023, Wang Di shared the new book at Xing Bookstore in Chengdu ; (Southern People Weekly reporter Wei Yi/Photo);

;

;Wang Di thought of his past. When the college entrance examination was resumed in 1977, Wang Di happened to be on a business trip in Shanghai. He has returned to Chengdu to work for two years. Before that, he worked in the countryside in Meishan, Su Dongpo's hometown. His elder brother had already gone to the Yunnan Production and Construction Corps. He could not have gone to the countryside, but if he didn't go to the countryside, there would be no future and no job arrangement. "I still want to go to the countryside. If I go to the countryside, I may have the opportunity to be recommended to go to university." Wang Di volunteered to go to the countryside and performed very well, but still did not get the chance to be recommended to go to university. In 1975, through recruitment, he returned to Chengdu and joined the Brick and Tile Factory of the Machinery Branch of the Chengdu Railway Bureau. "Burning bricks and tiles is absolutely hard physical labor."

;

;;I am in the brick kiln class. The brick kiln is oval, and the fire is eternal. Along the edge of the fire, there are many kiln fire cycles. After entering, it is like a tunnel. You transport bricks out of the kiln. In this weather, dog days, when you go in, the fire is It was hot. I only wore shorts and a mask when I went in. I was covered in sweat. Only my two eyes were exposed. The kiln dust was very heavy. Several people piled bricks up, the rhythm was as fast as doing exercise. At that time, the food stamps were rationed. Ordinary residents were given 26 kilograms per month. Because we were doing heavy manual labor, the food stamps were 46 kilograms. When you see this comparison, you know how heavy this labor is. Generally, factories work on an 8-hour working day, but we work on a 4-hour working day because we can't be too tired. This is a place no one wants to go. ;

;

;After working in the brick factory for more than a year, Wang Di was transferred to the labor union because he could draw. He painted many paintings and painted many slogans. He wanted to be a painter but had no chance. He failed to become a painter, but this amateur skill still gave him the opportunity to escape from heavy manual labor.

;

;The changing times gave him the opportunity to go to college. When China and the United States established diplomatic relations, he truly felt that times had changed. Wang Di, who had just entered college, wrote the following words in his diary on December 16, 1978: "What an outstanding initiative and a great step. China and the United States have officially established diplomatic relations. The grievances accumulated over the years will be It was quickly eliminated. In the morning, we were in the political and economics class in the first teaching building. When we heard this important news, everyone flushed with excitement. When we heard that Vice Chairman Deng would visit the United States in January next year, we all clapped. This fully illustrates the will of the people."

;

;;< /p>;

;Wang Di’s graduation photo from the History Department of Sichuan University;(provided by interviewee/picture );

;

;Although many years have passed, the scene of that day is still imprinted in Wang Di's mind. More than two hundred people from the 77th and 78th classes of the History Department took political economics classes in the largest classroom in the first teaching building. Because it is a large class, the classroom has radio and amplification equipment. During the break, one of the students turned on the radio. Through the loudspeaker, everyone heard the news about the establishment of diplomatic relations between China and the United States being broadcast by the Central People's Broadcasting Station. The noisy classroom fell silent, and then everyone applauded.

;

;The teaching building of the University of Macau is very quiet. An art exhibition by University of Macau faculty members is being held in the library. Three of Wang Di's paintings participated in the exhibition, but he was busy with work and had not seen them yet. He took us around the library several times before we found the exhibition hall. His paintings are placed in the most conspicuous position in the exhibition hall. The three portraits are of Fairbank, James Scott and Carlo Ginzburg, three scholars he admired.

;

;When writing a preface to Barbara Tuchman's book Stilwell, Fairbank said: "For a long time, the United States has tried to make China more like itself - this is a waste of time. Quixotic efforts, but failed many times, and now this kind of effort is rising again... 'In the end, China went its own way, as if Americans had never been there.'" Wang Di feels Fairbank's lifelong efforts were to strengthen the understanding and friendship between the people of China and the United States.

;

;When Wang Di was teaching undergraduates at Texas A&M University, he collected American media reports on the May Fourth Movement so that students could write papers based on these original materials. These sources, to his surprise, were largely unused by historians. "The American media mainly reports on major events in China, and also includes some introductions and analyzes of Chinese society and culture, as well as China's economy and education. The personal records I used and the media interviews with individuals are from their The China you see with your own eyes has details, stories, and feelings, which to a large extent make up for the lack of personal destiny and experience behind major events." Wang Di has always emphasized individuals and details.

;

;Macao is one of the important birthplaces of the Revolution of 1911. Sun Yat-sen practiced medicine here, and there is a statue of Sun Yat-sen in front of Jinghu Hospital. Wang Di recommended me to visit Morrison's tomb. "It's near the White Pigeon Nest, and it has a sense of history." When Wang Di's historian friends Yang Nianqun and Sun Jiang came to Macau, he took them there. Morrison edited and published the first English-Chinese dictionary, the Chinese-English Dictionary, was the first to translate the Bible into Chinese, and opened the first clinic integrating Chinese and Western medicine in Macau. He is a pioneering figure in Sino-Western exchanges, and Macao has historically been a bridgehead for Sino-Western exchanges.

;

;In the residence of the University of Macau, a waterway passes through the sea under the balcony. On one side of the sea is Macau and on the other side is Zhuhai. Seeing the coast reminds Wang Di of his fishing days in the United States. He has two major hobbies: fishing and growing vegetables. He planted many things on the balcony - Tianqi, cucumbers, fungus... and put aside his hobby of fishing. "It's not always good for a professor to fish on the coast next to the university." ;(laughing); On his balcony, he I never saw anyone fishing on the tidal flats.

;

;Wang Di has taught at universities in mainland China and the United States. Now that he has come to Macau, he feels that he has gained another perspective on thinking about history. Being at the junction of China and the West is helpful to his research. During the three years of the epidemic, many academic conferences have been suspended. After having this meal with us in Macau, Wang Di is going to Hong Kong to attend a meeting of Chinese and foreign historians. The conference does not require everyone to write a paper, but just talks about some recent ideas. Wang Di plans to take a bus to Hong Kong and take the Hong Kong-Zhuhai-Macao Bridge.

;

;Reading

;

;In Macau, Wang Di rarely went to teahouses. He likes roadside stalls. He introduced us to a shop near White Pigeon Nest to eat curry beef soup. "The shop is right on the street, and diners eat on the street. It's delicious. I eat it every time I pass by." Children who come from such a shop facing the street, in the words of Wang Di's classmate Wang Hai, are "street eaters." Baby". Wang Hai said that he is a "street kid". Unlike Wang Di who grew up in a compound, "street kid" needs stronger ability to get around. Wang Hai feels that artists can get away with it, but historians cannot. This is the difference between the two.

;

;A few years ago, Wang Di had a conversation with Liushahe, which made him feel nervous. When he was a child, he and Liushahe lived in the courtyard of the Sichuan Federation of Literary and Art Circles, and he and his brother would go to Liushahe to listen to stories. Also living in this courtyard are Sha Ting, Ai Wu and others. Wang Di's historical writing has literary and aesthetic self-requirements, which is probably related to the influence of the humanistic environment he grew up in. But those were not peaceful days. When he wanted to study, he had to sneak into the library of the Federation of Literary and Art Circles Library. It was an era when reading was like a thief. Wang Di only attended elementary school for three years, and did not complete middle school or high school. In high school, due to political review, he almost lost the opportunity to enter a higher education. But his habit of reading helped him. When the college entrance examination suddenly resumed, he was not so unprepared.

;

;When the college entrance examination was resumed in 1977, Wang Di was 21 years old and working in the railway bureau trade union. Train tickets are free and you can walk everywhere. The union provides good benefits and will be allocated some scarce goods. His parents felt that the job at the Railway Bureau was an iron rice bowl. Even if he went to college, the job assigned after graduation would not necessarily be better than it is now. They suggested that he wait for another two years. After working for five years, he could study with pay, and he could return to school after graduation. original unit. After listening to his parents' advice, Wang Di did not take the college entrance examination in 1977. On the day of the college entrance examination, he happened to be on a business trip to Shanghai. Although he was a worker at that time, he "worked for work", that is, doing cadre work as a worker, which seemed quite comfortable. In Shanghai, he happened to see candidates entering the college entrance examination examination room. Such a scene is a stimulus to him. He felt very lost, "a feeling of being abandoned by the times." At that moment, he decided that he must take the exam next year, "I can't wait any longer."

;

;He prepared secretly and did not dare to tell his parents. "What if I give up again if they try to persuade me?" At that time, he lived in a work unit and went home once a week. He didn't mention it when he got back, and only told his parents after the exam. The parents are still very happy. My grades were pretty good, and I did particularly well on the history test. I originally wanted to study Chinese, but actually I still wanted to draw. I felt that studying Chinese and art had something to do with it.

;

;When I first met Wang Di at Chengdu Heming Tea House, he had just attended the 40th anniversary party of his college classmates the night before. Students still remember that Wang Di was the first student admitted to the History Department of Sichuan University in 1978. He scored 96 out of 100 points in history. When he went to report, it was No. 1. "Actually, I didn't know what historical research was at that time. I just liked reading some history books." The composition of my college classmates was very complicated. When I first entered school, the youngest student in the class was 16 years old and the oldest was 32 years old. "Now I can't tell my age, almost all of them are retired. There are groups of students who specialize in traveling, groups that specialize in drinking, and groups that specialize in playing mahjong."

;

;Among college classmates like Wang Di are still there There are very few people working. Wang Di is a chair professor at the University of Macau and can retire at the age of 70. For the 40th anniversary party, the students planned to go to Anren Town for two days. Wang Di has something to do and has to return to Macau. The classmates in Chengdu decided to get together in Chengdu one day in advance in order to meet Wang Di.

;

;Wang Di behaves in a low-key manner. Every time he returns to Chengdu, he comes and leaves quietly. This time I returned to Chengdu, there were many public events, and I couldn’t hide them. Everyone gathered together. "I don't want to be the protagonist and let others do the activities for you."

;

;He went to see his parents. My parents are in their nineties and live in a nursing home. A large number of books in Chengdu had been unused for many years, so he donated them to Sichuan University and let the graduate students divide them. Now, he misses those books a little bit. It was with those books that he wrote his first book - "Out of the Closed World".

;

;After so many years abroad, he used the newly collected research materials to write "Street Culture", "Brother Pao", "Teahouse" and other works. Chengdu Shuangliu District is currently preparing to build a Wang Di Documentation Center. The materials he collected will be placed here in the future and can be used by other researchers in need. Wang Di just visited this place. The documentation center has two floors and is very beautiful. Wang Hai is helping him do this. Wang Hai appeared in many of Wang Di's activities. He has a completely opposite personality to Wang Di. Even the word "social cow" is not enough to describe him.

;

;In Macau, there are not many books on Wang Di’s bookshelf. He hardly collects books now. They are too heavy and inconvenient for him to use often. He mainly reads e-books and often listens to books. He has bad eyesight. He showed me the e-books he was reading, including Scott, Hayek, Wang Dingjun, and the newly minted Nobel Prize winner in Literature Anne Ernault. He wanted to tell the story of "Tea House" in the voice of a virtual century-old man, similar to Ernault's "Unauthorized Autobiography" in "Years of Time". While Erno recalls himself, he also triggers the memories of others, and the resonance of memories shows the evolution of the times.

;

;Wang Di has been looking for these resonant moments in his memory. A lot of these moments are sinking. For example, when he was making bricks in a brick and tile factory, he was crowded into a large shed with twenty or thirty workers and had no private space of his own. While the workers were sleeping, he read under the lamp, but no one said that he kept the lamp on so late that it affected their sleep. The workers also made him a table out of scrap wood so that he could read and draw. "It's probably the experience during that period that had a subtle influence on my later public view of history and the perspective of the lower class."

;

;In Youxing Bookstore, Wang Di talked about his generation, both Urban intellectuals who have been farmers and workers may be a unique generation in Chinese history. At the age of 22 - neither too early nor too late - he passed the sudden college entrance examination and turned his destiny around. At the age of 31, he became the youngest associate professor in the history department of a Chinese university at that time. When everything seemed to be going smoothly, he made the decision to go to the United States to study for graduate school and start over.

;

;In the United States

;

;When Wang Di, associate professor of the History Department of Sichuan University, was preparing to continue his studies abroad, he received admission notices from the history departments of two American universities. One is Johns Hopkins University and the other is Columbia University. He chose the former and studied for a doctorate with the famous American historian William Rowe.

;

;William Luo recommended Wang Di to read "Cheese and Maggots" by Carlo Ginzburg. This is Wang Di’s first time reading a micro-historical work. Ginzburg used the Inquisition archives to write the spiritual history of Menocchio, a small rural miller in northern Italy in the 16th century. Menocchio saw the universe as a piece of cheese riddled with maggots. The original work is in Italian, and the English version Wang Di read happens to be published by Johns Hopkins University Press. He read this micro-history classic countless times, and later in the New Cultural History discussion class he taught, he went over the details of the book with his students again and again. He believes that such intensive reading and discussion are more useful than giving students a long book list.

;

;Wang Di writes micro history. His three major topics were fully discussed with William Luo. When William Luo teaches his students, he doesn’t just tell them what he is good at, and then just let the students write about what they are good at. "The students themselves have to have this impulse, and the teacher helps to deepen it. It does not mean that the teacher has a big idea and then assigns it to the students."

;

;When he discussed writing his doctoral thesis with William Luo, there was no " The word "street culture" ;(street culture);. "I introduced this concept first, and he said yes. I think students should think independently and deepen continuously. The teacher should make the problem concrete, rather than letting the teacher think for him."

;

;Wang Di has been practicing this Take a microscopic view of history. He feels that this requires more adaptation and understanding for us readers who are accustomed to historical writing having great significance and grand narratives. It’s not about more and more detailed historical writing, it’s about micro history. "If we write a book about Zeng Guofan or Hu Shi, no matter how detailed and detailed it is, it will not be what we call micro history. One of the prerequisites of micro history is to write the history of ordinary people."

;

;Ginzburg advocated paying attention to "the persecuted and subjugated people" because these people are often "dismissed or even completely ignored by many historians as marginal figures."

;

;When Wang Di was writing his doctoral thesis "Street Culture" using micro-historical methods, his supervisor William Luo was writing "Salvation - Chen Hongmou and the Elite Consciousness of Eighteenth-Century China". William Luo believes that this Qing Dynasty official, who was born in Hengshan Village, Lingui, Guangxi, can see the mentality of the elite at that time. This is a model of "managing the world" and the epitome of the prosperous Qing Dynasty. Obviously the research that Wang Di is interested in is different, but this does not prevent them from going to the Library of Congress to look up materials together. "This may be the place with the most books and materials in the world." Luo William went to find Chen Hongmou, and Wang Di went to the teahouse. William Luo would ask Wang Di how to translate these lines of Chen Hongmou's poems appropriately.

;

;;

;

;Wang Di shared with readers in Chengdu;(Hua Xiaofeng/Photo);

;

;William Luo He expressed his thoughts in the introduction to "Salvation": "Now it seems that narrative works and intensive reading of historical texts are completely necessary. The emphasis on micro history has made the detailed study of the personal lives of historical figures extremely valuable. High status. "Cheese and Maggots" by Italian historian Carlo Ginzburg is a classic in micro-historical research. This makes me suspect that in this era, a scholar spent a lot of time studying a male elite Is it the most effective way to do research with an important political figure? Many articles published by Giovanni Levi, a high-spirited Italian historian, in the "Annals" eloquently prove: Those who study big figures, such as Proper treatment, like the study of small figures, can help us understand past history."

;

;Many people will also think that Wang Di's micro-historical research is similar to another historian Yang Nianqun's study of emperors. research will produce conflicts and contradictions. Wang Di doesn't see it that way. "Actually, what we are saying is not contradictory. History is indeed determined by emperors and elites in many cases. He is telling the truth, but what I express is a view of history. Those who rule people should study it, and the people who are ruled should also study it. Yang Nianqun Studying the emperor does not mean that he agrees with the emperor's approach."

;

;Wang Di learned a lot from William Luo, including that a mentor does not dominate everything. Wang Di now teaches students New Cultural History at the University of Macau. Read original English works such as "Cheese and Maggots" by Ginzburg and "The Return of Martin Guerre" by Natalie Zemon Davis. Read a book every two weeks, 3 hours a week, and discuss a book 6 hours a week. He works out every detail with his students. He encourages students to think independently and put forward different opinions to teachers with reason and evidence. Sometimes the opinions are right, but sometimes they are not necessarily right. The opinions of both teachers and students are not unquestionable. "This is a way of dialogue, not to prove who is right or wrong. Sometimes everyone uses the same information in different ways. There are multiple perspectives for interpreting history, but everything is based on careful reading. Go up."

;

;As mentioned before, Wang Di also received an admission notice from the History Department of Columbia University that year. The person who admitted him was historian Zeng Xiaoping ; (Madeleine Zelin) ;. Her representative work is "Zigong Merchants: Entrepreneurs in Early Modern China" 》. When Wang Di's doctoral thesis "Street Culture" was published by Stanford University Press, one of the anonymous external reviewers was Zeng Xiaoping.

;

;;

;

;Wang Di growing vegetables on the balcony;(Southern People Weekly reporter Fang Yingzhong/picture);

;

; Zeng Xiaoping wrote six or seven pages of comments for "Street Culture", which is equivalent to a small essay. She gave Wang Di many suggestions for revision, one of which was: the point of view of this book is not very clear. This troubled Wang Di. "I asked William Luo how to highlight the main points. William Luo told me a method. He said, you use one sentence to summarize each chapter, and then you combine these words in each chapter into a paragraph, and the theme of that paragraph This sentence is your main point. This is amazing."

;

;In 2005, "Street Culture" won the Best Book Award from the American Society for Urban History Research. Wang Di is grateful to both Zeng Xiaoping and Luo William. He has benefited a lot from the strict review questions and the effective methods to solve them.

;

;William Luo is over seventy years old, less than ten years older than Wang Di. Sometimes, Wang Di would ask William Luo for advice. 2019, co-recommended by William Luo and his colleague Tobie Meyer-Fong at Hopkins University , Wang Di was selected as the school's outstanding alumnus ;(Soecity of Scholars);, which is a great honor. Wang Di was originally going to the United States to attend an awards ceremony and attend a dinner hosted by the principal in the spring of 2020. He had invited William Luo to attend, but due to epidemic restrictions, he was unable to make the trip. This was his biggest regret during the epidemic.

;

;In the American history community, it is not easy for Chinese professors to gain recognition. Wang Di talked about He Bingdi and Huang Renyu, thinking that they are two extreme examples of Chinese American historical scholars. "He Bingdi's research method is orthodox in the field of American history. He pays attention to empirical evidence and can be recognized professionally. He has had a smooth sailing. He served as the president of the Asia Society of America in the 1970s. This is not easy. Huang Renyu is the other extreme. His The book is written in the style of big history, such as "The Fifteen Years of Wanli", which lacks a basis for case study and is difficult to be accepted by American historians. Therefore, the publication of his book in the United States suffered many setbacks, and in the end he even lost his teaching position. Huang Renyu's books span thousands of years and are very comfortable to read. Today, Huang Renyu's reputation among readers is far greater than that of He Bingdi, and "Yellow River and Green Mountains" is more shocking to read than "Sixty Years of Reading History and Reading the World"."

;

;When Wang Di taught at Texas A&M University, he was the only Chinese professor in the history department. As he gets older, the biggest headache for Wang Di is the inconvenient transportation. There is an airport in the university. If he wants to return to China, he needs to take a small plane from the university town to Houston, Austin or Dallas, then fly to Los Angeles or San Francisco, and then fly to Beijing or Shanghai.

;

;He has taught in the United States for 17 years, from assistant professor to full professor, and felt that he needed to change his environment. When the University of Macau offered him an olive branch, he accepted it and came to the University of Macau in 2015. After a year of adapting, he stayed and served as chairman of the History Department of the University of Macau and as a chair professor to this day.

;

;Rolling waves

;

;In Macau, Wang Di often eats in the canteen, or solves problems at home with noodles and frozen dumplings. When I occasionally cook Sichuan cuisine, I take the simplest approach and use hot pot base ingredients to cook various side dishes. The Hengqin campus of the University of Macau is connected to Macau through an undersea tunnel. It is like a small society, so Wang Di can stay away from the hustle and bustle.

;

;His desk faces the balcony diagonally, and the ship outside the floor-to-ceiling window passes through the traffic artery of reality and history. He seems to be living between history and reality. He is a scholar who has both a sense of history and a sense of reality. He hopes to use his thinking about history to make sense of the present. "History is full of contingency and has no rules, but history can help us think."

;

;There are many pictures and photos on the wall outside Wang Di's office, including an introduction to his professional research and photos of his daily life. One of the photos is from a college class reunion in 2000. The students are playing mahjong. Wang Di cannot play mahjong, and before studying teahouses, he rarely went to teahouses. He doesn't look like a typical Chengdu person. Maybe a "street kid" like his classmate Wang Hai is.

;

;Wang Di may have wanted to be a painter more than Wang Hai. His illustrations often appear in his books, such as the Heming Teahouse where we are chatting. He drew one based on the photo. He drew many portraits for "The Whisper of History". "This is in line with my philosophy. They are people I admire. I draw ideas and reflections from them. To display these requires artistic techniques and some illustrations. I don't like to simply put photos. "The Tea Shop on the Corner "I also drew illustrations. The idea of ​​drawing illustrations was a consensus reached by me and Li Lei, the editor in charge of these two books."

;

;Over the years, Wang Di has published many books in China, many of which You need to queue up to get to each publishing house to avoid crashing on the press. He is very satisfied with the "Wang Di's Works Series" being launched by the People's Literature Publishing House. "The editor-in-chief Li Lei thought of a lot of options just for the title of each book. In terms of literary expression and public reading and promotion, it is also He gave me a lot of tips and suggestions, and arranged a conversation between me and Xu Jilin at the Shanghai Book Fair, as well as Zhang Mingyang and I’s activities in Sinan, Shanghai.” Wang Di said that in the United States for more than 20 years, the things he published were not many. "I went to the United States in 1991. By 2015, I had only published two English books and one Chinese book in 24 years. It was very few, but a lot of things were accumulated, and after accumulation, they would explode." Wang Di is 67 years old this year . There is a saying that the age between 60 and 70 is the golden period for a historian. Wang Di is in such a period.

;

;On the way to Heming Tea House, he had been listening to books. "I have bad eyesight, so I keep my eyes open for writing." He is a person who cherishes time. When he gets up in the morning, he rinses his mouth and brushes his teeth, cooks and eats, and listens to books. He said that his life is composed of three books: writing, reading, and teaching.

;

;In Macau, following Wang Di’s instructions, I found Morrison’s tomb in the corner behind a church in front of White Pigeon Nest. On the site in front of the tomb, there were several workers pulling wires to measure. It was estimated that the church and cemetery needed repairs. A few children were playing football in front of the church, and they would run over only when the ball went into the yard. The area in front of the White Pigeon Nest is a public space, and most of the people here are old people playing chess. Tradition is as solid as stone. Wang Di said that similar scenes can be seen in Hong Kong and San Francisco. Some of the components of public space that are inherited from tradition do not change with time.

;

;In September 2023, I also saw people playing chess in front of the Guanyin Pavilion Teahouse in Peng Town, Shuangliu, Chengdu. They sat there all morning. Wang Di's "Teahouse;(Part 2);" recounts Zhang Rong's memories in "Hong: The Story of Three Generations of Chinese Women". Many teahouses in Chengdu were forcibly closed at the beginning of the Cultural Revolution. "One boy even lifted the chessboard and all the chess pieces fell on the floor, shouting: 'No chess! Don't you know this is a bourgeois hobby?' Then he threw the chess pieces and the board into the river. Some students were in the teahouse. Paint slogans on the walls."

;

;During the "Destroy the Four Olds" movement, teahouses were impacted, where drinking tea "was seen as a bad habit of the old society, and tea shops were seen as harboring dirt and evil. The teahouses were forcibly banned and closed down as a gathering place for class dissidents and backward masses.” At this time, Laohu Zao still played an important role in the lives of Chengdu residents. In the 1960s, Chengdu residents were short of fuel at home, so the boiling water provided by Laohu Zao was more convenient and cheaper than boiling water themselves. There are fewer people drinking tea in teahouses, but the number of people buying boiled water to make tea at home has not decreased.茶铺起到水铺的作用。

;

;在茶馆研究的问题上，王笛关心的是，是否地区或地方的研究可以提供理解中国社会和文化的普遍性知识。 “微观研究的意义在于，能够为把对历史的认识上升到一个更广义的层次提供个案分析，其不仅能丰富我们对地方的知识，而且有助于我们对中国的理解。”

;

;国家与社会关系问题，是西方研究中国历史的一个着眼点。在1980年代末和1990年代初，罗威廉使用公共领域;（public sphere）;这一概念来研究近代中国时，遭到不少学者反对，他们认为哈贝马斯的概念不适用于中国。 “20世纪下半叶的中国有相当长一段时间，便处于有'国家'无'社会'的时代，国家掌握了政治、经济、社会、文化的一切资源，这是此前任何政权未能实现的。传统的'公'的领域也几乎不复存在。”

;

;姜文导演的《让子弹飞》已然是当代中国电影的经典之作，其中的桥段脍炙人口，在各种社交场合被频频引用。电影改编自马识途《夜谭十记》中的《盗官记》。在《盗官记》里，有这么一段对成都茶馆的细致描述：

;

;;你们去过成都吗？那里有一个少城公园，少城公园里有一个鹤鸣茶社。在那里有一块颇大的空坝子，都盖着凉棚，面临绿水涟漪，是个好的风景去处。凉棚下摆满茶桌和竹椅，密密麻麻坐满喝茶的茶客，热闹得很。到处听到互相打招呼、寒暄问好的声音，到处是茶倌放下铜盘叫着“开水”的声音。这是一个普通的茶座，那些做小生意的、当教员的等等小市民们，就在这里来谋事，说合，讲交情，做买卖，吵架，扯皮，参加“六腊之战”，“吃讲茶”……;

;

;这是曾经的鹤鸣茶社，许多情状还在，许多则已成往事。比如说“六腊之战”，指的是每年六月和腊月是学校教员受聘期满的月份，教员们为了争取继续聘用，四处奔走，为生活而战。 “吃讲茶”则是双方发生争执时，会请袍哥主持公道，双方在茶馆谈判，或和或打，就看这茶吃得怎样。

;

;;

;

;王笛在成都鹤鸣茶社拍摄茶客;（华小峰/图）;

;

;马识途的小说写的是民国时的事情。 1949年之后，马识途的回忆是这样的：

;

;;既然茶馆不再是能支持革命的地方，我们必须坚决地消除它们。因此，茶馆倒闭了。尽管人们不喜欢这种不便，但他们除了无条件服从外，无能为力。实际上，一些有识之士认为我们可以取茶馆之益而去其之弊，当然，这样的话，茶馆的弊处将会完全被消除，茶馆将成为一个文化活动中心以及宣传教育的场所。但当局没有听见这些声音，因此，茶馆在四川大地上几乎消失殆尽。 ;

;

;王笛觉得鹤鸣茶社的历史几乎可以单独提出来独立成书，鹤鸣茶社的历史就是一部波澜起伏的电影，而不同人的眼中，有不同的茶和历史——

;

;;看到同样的历史资料，人和人理解不一样。我们今天在鹤鸣茶社，可能不同的人有不同的感受。有的人可能看到脏乱差，有的人看到的是人和人在聊天社交，有的人看到茶倌在忙着掺茶，有的是看到谋生的人，有的看到掏耳朵的人，有的是看到我们在这聊天，摆着书，还有人在旁边照相。每个人看到的都不一样。本来这就是一个大千世界。卡尔·波普尔说，我们写不出整体的历史，包括鹤鸣茶社，我们都写不出整体的历史。我们看到的只是通过个体的眼睛，或者个体的研究者来理解的历史，任何历史都只是部分的历史。每个人写的都是碎片，不可能是全面的历史。 ;

;

;;有的人说成都很好啊，有的人说成都就是大家无所事事。同样的事情，有的是积极的，有的是消极的。大家的经历不一样。有的工作很满意，有的始终找不到好工作，能说感受是一样的吗？历史就这样复杂，没有标准，也没有规律。相信历史有规律是很可怕的事情。过去的三年，病毒让全球都改变了。这有什么必然性啊。三年前，没有人预见得到疫情对世界的改变。所谓规律，是可以预见到的未来，历史真的不是这样的，很多时候只是人的一念之差。我们的现代社会，整个人类文明，不是人为设计的，一个社会自然进化可能更合理。 ;

;

;王笛从鹤鸣茶社旁边人头攒动的餐饮店里买了几碗水饺，这是我们的午餐。他说起吃的历史。 “我读幼儿园的时候，吃不饱饭，我还记得，小孩子跟着老师去其他班看看有没有剩下的饭，没有啊。这样的饿肚子的事情，就是人为设计的结果。”王笛生于1956年。

;

;他表达了他对整个中国历史的看法。 “我们要让社会充分发展。举个简单的例子，如果大家都在泰坦尼克号这样的大船上，如果在正确的航道上，大家没感觉有什么，一旦出现问题，大家就都完蛋。如果我们分乘50条船往前走，看起来缺乏效率，但哪一种选择更安全，这是非常简单的道理。”

;

;在《茶馆;（上）;》的尾声，王笛用了《寻梦》作为标题。他用非常感性的笔触描述了1949年的最后一天：

;

;;在过去的50年里，他们所光顾的茶馆，他们视为理所当然的坐茶馆的生活习惯，竟一直是国家权力与地方社会、文化的同一性和独特性较量的“战场”。他们每天到茶馆吃茶，竟然就是他们拿起“弱者的武器”所进行的“弱者的反抗”。这也即是说，弱小而手无寸铁的茶馆经理人、堂倌和茶客们，在这50年的反复鏖战中，任凭茶碗中波澜翻滚，茶桌上风云变幻，他们犹如冲锋陷阵的勇士，为茶馆和日常文化的最终胜利，立下了汗马功劳。如果他们知道自己在捍卫地方文化中所扮演的关键角色，就不会嘲笑这位通过时间机器突然降临、要为他们撰写历史的小同乡了。 ;

;

;“小同乡”指的是王笛自己。 2023年9月，王笛第九次来到成都双流彭镇观音阁茶馆，时间机器仿佛再次启程。他毫无意外地再次看到了在那里打牌的甘大爷和胡大爷。老板李强用老虎灶上取下来的水壶给他们的茶杯里倒入鲜开水，波澜翻滚。

;

;在王笛叙述的那些试图改变世界的大人物眼中，他们想着的是世界的波澜翻滚，而不是这碗茶。王笛在《历史的微声》最后一章中，提到了他脑海里浮现过的一个画面：“帝王或者英雄站在高高的山巅上，俯瞰整个大地，为自己马上要创造历史，而心潮澎湃，豪情万丈。极目望去，在他的眼中，是乌泱泱的人海，芸芸众生，小如蝼蚁。对他来说，面对这样的人海，多一个不多，少一个也不少，个体在这里已经失去了意义；个体的命运，在这里是无关大局的；芸芸众生之间，是没有区别的，甚至看不清他们的面孔。他们没有自己的故事，也没有自己的历史，当然也就没有自己的未来。如果这些芸芸众生为了帝王或者英雄所谓的'宏大事业'而死去，就无声无息地化为了尘土。在宏大的历史叙事中，个体是整体完全可以忽视的东西，这就是整体史的本质。”

;

;在观音阁茶馆，王笛走到甘大爷和胡大爷旁边，再次拍下了许多照片。而正在打牌的两位大爷对此习以为常，连眼皮都没抬一下。每天上午都出现在茶馆里，用一杯一块钱的茶度过一个上午，这样波澜不惊的生活也许才是最正常最让人安心的生活。王笛告诉我，“人民能够日复一日、年复一年预期到他们能够过着安静和平的生活，难道这不就是最宏大的叙事吗？”

;

;真实是什么？

;

;王笛在办公室收到了四川大学学报寄给他的期刊。期刊的开篇便是他写的论文《“啯匪”和“会匪”：哥老会起源的新思考》。秘密会社一直是他所关心的主题。当年的《袍哥》是这一研究过程中的插曲。和袍哥有关的大量材料需要更丰富的形式来表现。对沈宝媛论文的研究，更像是对《奶酪与蛆虫》的一次具体的借鉴。 “原本并不打算写微观史，只是正好有这么一个资料。”意大利偏远地区的故事勾起他对四川乡下一起案件的联系。这正说明文明当中的许多形式具有共性，我们跟世界并不是那么不一样。

;

;最近他会写到“三支半香”，会写到哥老会现实和精神的起源。他会运用霍布斯鲍姆《传统的发明》所提到的理念。袍哥联系着更繁复而未明的历史。如何认识这些故事，如何认识文本，如何认识档案，是重要的事情。 “不要认为记载在档案上的东西就是历史。档案的真实性并不比别人写的小说更真实。”王笛说起二十四史。 “二十四史就是官修的历史。这是皇帝希望我们相信的历史。许多历史经过伪造、修改，甚至销毁。如果没有二十四史，今天留给我们的历史，也许不是更少，而是更多。这些官修的历史有多少真实性？我敢说百分之一的真实性都没有。官修的历史只能代表官方，跟每个人的经历有出入。我反复强调，一个学者要有批判精神，包括对史料和历史写作的批判，没有批判的话，你的写作没有任何意义。当然，每个人都没法写出完全真实的历史，我们只是力图写出接近真实的历史。”

;

;;

;

;王笛在澳门大学校园里;（南方人物周刊记者方迎忠/图）;

;

;我和王笛站在下班高峰期的成都合江亭附近的路边等车。往西边走一段路，就到新南门。以前，成都还有城墙城门城楼的时候，南门叫“江桥”，南城楼是“浣溪”。顺着锦江往西边的方向看，看到的是和其他城市差不多的天际线，看不出这是成都。往东不远的地方是九眼桥遗迹。成都许多地方只剩下一个地名。那些貌似还在的地方，跟往年已经不一样。锦里、宽窄巷子好像是古色古香的街道，但保留下来的东西并不多。王笛原本住在大慈寺对面，庙里曾经有一个文博大茶园，“非常壮观”。他觉得这里曾是最有成都茶馆文化特色的地方，但已经有了翻天覆地的变化，成了太古里。文博大茶园长大的孩子和太古里长大的孩子看到的成都，哪个更真实？

;

;成都是和茶馆相连的，茶馆让成都成为成都。 “到口子上啖三花”曾经是成都人的口头禅，就像北京人说“您吃了吗”一样。不一定真的去喝茶或吃饭。一种可以成为日常口语的指代物，说明这件事情在日常生活中的重要。在口子上，在街角，那种传统茶铺不好找了。所以，游客们会去双流彭镇的茶馆打卡。

;

;王笛在观音阁茶馆门口跟老板李强聊起过去。他觉得观音阁茶馆现在的“两张皮”挺好。 “一张皮”是网红打卡之地。他们在这里喝一碗茶10块钱，买了茶可以喝茶休息拍照。 “另一张皮”是当地茶客的日常生活，以甘大爷和胡大爷每天雷打不动出现在茶馆为标志，他们用的是大茶杯，茶叶不一样，1块钱。两者相辅相成，构成了一个传统和现实融合的空间。

;

;这里是成都历史为数不多的“活化石”之一。未硬化的室内泥地，土木结构的空间，竹椅、温水瓶、茶碗、老虎灶，各种嘈杂声随之而来。这是现实的声音，也是历史的回声。这是王笛所说的“历史的微声”。这里，普通的个体不是一个个抽象数字，而是一个个具体的人。他们喝着茶，打着牌，聊着天，将生活日复一日地进行下去。

;

;

; Wed, 04 Oct 2023 10:25:05 +0800 专访魏纪中：亚运会溢出的正面社会效应越来越大http://www.infzm.com/contents/258062
;;2023-10-04 09:00:00;
;

;87 is an age long overdue for retirement, but Wei Jizhong plans to work longer. "The healthiest person in New China" Ma John's words have always inspired him: "A person has to work for the sports industry for 50 years." Now, he can proudly say: "I have far exceeded it.";

;;

;

;On September 22, 2023, Wei Jizhong, the lifelong honorary vice president of the Olympic Council of Asia, answered reporters' questions at the media briefing of the Olympic Council of Asia and the Hangzhou Asian Organizing Committee. ;(Visual China/Photo);

;

;In 1958, there were two roads before Wei Jizhong: one led to the People's Literature Publishing House, This is in line with the outside world's expectations for a graduate of Nanjing University's French literature major; another path leads to the National Sports Commission (now the State Sports General Administration), which stems from the inner expectations of a young volleyball player. Wei Jizhong decided to follow his heart. He is fluent in English and French, which allowed him to quickly participate in the external relations of New China Sports. He is one of the people in the country who has the most contacts with International Olympic Committee President Juan Antonio Samaranch. During his sixty-five years of ambitious sports work, he participated in almost all major sports events in New China.

;

;Since 1986, Wei Jizhong has served as the Secretary-General of the Chinese Olympic Committee, and then became the Vice-Chairman of the Chinese Olympic Committee. Wei Jizhong believes that sports can show a more "open" China to the world. Wei Jizhong, who is well versed in the rules of international sports affairs, has held many important positions in the International Volleyball Federation and the Asian Olympic Council. People believe that Wei Jizhong was one of the key figures in the successful Beijing Olympic bid in 2008. He put forward many constructive suggestions for the Olympic bid and was the "bridge" between the Chinese Olympic Committee and the International Olympic Committee.

;

;During the Hangzhou Asian Games, Wei Jizhong still maintained high energy. His work schedule was full and he had to stay until the end of the Asian Games. As the lifelong honorary vice president of the Olympic Council of Asia, Wei Jizhong participated in the official press conference of the Asian Organizing Committee, accepted media interviews, and responded to issues related to the Asian Games.

;

;On September 29, 2023, Wei Jizhong accepted an exclusive interview with a Southern Weekend reporter in Hangzhou.

;

;"More and more countries and regions hope to host the Asian Games"

;

;;Southern Weekend:;;The Hangzhou Asian Games is the third Asian Games hosted by China. What are the differences between the hosting backgrounds of the three Asian Games? ;

;

;;Wei Jizhong:;;When we held the Beijing Asian Games in 1990, it was mainly for external needs after the reform and opening up. That Asian Games was originally supposed to be held in Hiroshima, Japan. Later, we negotiated with the Hiroshima Organizing Committee of Japan through the Olympic Council of Asia and asked them to give us the 1990 Asian Games first, and then they would host the 1994 Asian Games. The committee agreed, and we were qualified to host the Asian Games in Beijing in 1990. ;

;

;In the 2010 Guangzhou Asian Games, some changes occurred in the political background. After Comrade Xiaoping's talks in the south, reform and opening up entered a new stage. Against this background, Guangzhou began to bid for the Asian Games. Hangzhou's hosting of the Asian Games is based on the obvious achievements of the entire reform and opening up. We must further open up and use opening up to promote reform. Against this background, we applied to host the Hangzhou Asian Games again.

;

;After hosting the Asian Games three times, the overall environment of the entire country and the overall environment of the world are different. So I say that every Asian Games has its own significance, and in addition to the significance of sports, it also has different social and political significance.

;

;;

;

;September 2023, Hangzhou Olympic Sports Center Stadium at night. ;(Visual China/Photo);

;

;;Southern Weekend:;;The Asian Games have been held for a total of nineteen times. This is your eleventh time to participate in the Asian Games. In your opinion, is the Asian Games becoming more and more difficult to host? ;

;

;;Wei Jizhong:;;My opinion is exactly the opposite. Judging from the current situation, more and more countries and regions hope to host the Asian Games: the next one will be held in Nagoya, Japan, and Japan will be followed by countries and regions such as Qatar and Saudi Arabia. Therefore, the Asian Games is becoming more and more difficult to host and is inconsistent with the actual situation. ;

;

;In addition, from the perspective of our hosting of the Asian Games, in addition to promoting the development of sports, the positive social effects of the Asian Games are getting bigger and bigger. In 2006, Qatar took the opportunity of hosting the Asian Games to transform Qatar from a relatively simple oil export economy into a relatively comprehensive open economy. At that time, Qatar only had one international hotel and no high-rise buildings. If you go to Doha (the capital of Qatar) today and see it, everything has changed. Since the Doha (Asian Games), many countries and regions have realized that the social and economic benefits overflowed by hosting the Asian Games can promote the development of the entire country. This is an increasingly consistent understanding. Moreover, the Olympic Council of Asia also helps various countries and regions to produce relatively sustained social and economic benefits while hosting the Asian Games.

;

;In order to let more countries win medals

;

;;Southern Weekend:;; In 1990, the Beijing Asian Games had 27 major events and 308 minor events (gold medals). The Hangzhou Asian Games had 40 major events and 481 minor events (gold medals). The Asian Games had many events, many types, and many gold medals. Why would the Asian Games consider setting up so many events? , will this reduce the competitiveness of sports? ;

;

;;Wei Jizhong:;;Why have we added so many projects? The purpose is to promote the development of sports in Asia, mainly in developing countries. After years of exploration, we have found that (this) mainly relies on the support of the government and the recognition of sports by the whole society. These two points can be achieved through the Asian Games. ;

;

;We set up more events to enable athletes from more countries and regions to achieve good results in the Asian Games, that is, to win medals. For a country where sports are relatively underdeveloped, if athletes can win gold medals or medals through their performance at the Asian Games, it will be an inspiration to the people and the government will be satisfied. Once the government is satisfied, it will have more support for other sports. Therefore, we at the Asian Olympic Committee have adopted an open policy. These open policies are to allow athletes from some sports underdeveloped countries to have the opportunity to participate in the activities of the Asian Games family.

;

;The Olympic Games is mainly a competition for some elite athletes. Of course, it also takes care of the masses, but it is mainly a competition for elite athletes. Therefore, the International Olympic Committee and the Organizing Committee bear all costs. The Asian Games is a paid event, which means each athlete and official must pay US$50 per day. Of course, this 50 US dollars is not enough (to cover the cost), and the organizing committee will subsidize them some. For example, the meal standard for athletes at the Hangzhou Asian Games is 500 yuan, which exceeds the fees paid. The government's willingness to pay to allow athletes to participate in competitions shows the government's support for sports.

;

;Now, more and more athletes are participating in the Asian Games, which has exceeded the number of participants in the Olympic Games. This shows that Asian sports are developing. We set up more projects, especially some local traditional projects, so that more national and regional Olympic committees can achieve results at the games. Now, the proportion of medals won by the Olympic committees of the countries and regions we participate in has exceeded 80%. Doing so can indeed promote sports and development in developing countries and regions, and society will increasingly recognize sports.

;

;;Southern Weekend:;;E-sports is one of the projects that has attracted much attention at the Hangzhou Asian Games. Regarding the entry of e-sports into Asia, the Olympic Council of Asia, the State Sports General Administration and the Hangzhou Asian Organizing Committee have conducted many studies and discussions. How was the final decision made? ;

;

;;Wei Jizhong:;;E-sports was developed from video games and is similar to traditional sports. Some traditional sports, including football, basketball, and volleyball, have also transitioned from popular entertainment projects to formal competitions. Video games and e-sports have a large and wide-ranging group. Professional players come from this group. Their talents in traditional sports may not be that high, but they may have greater development in e-sports. Since such a group exists, we cannot ignore it. ;

;

;We have a process of understanding e-sports. E-sports is a sport. This is controversial because e-sports does not match the definition of sports in the dictionary. However, from a sports perspective, the competitive side of e-sports is consistent with the definition of sports.

;

;Chairman Mao Zedong said, "Develop sports and enhance people's physical fitness." He distinguished sports from sports. The two have similarities and differences. I agree with the view that e-sports is not only a sport, but also a cultural and creative project.

;

;We have continued to communicate with the International Olympic Committee on this issue, and e-sports has continued to improve. The International Olympic Committee has gradually recognized that e-sports has many aspects in common with traditional sports. Therefore, the International Olympic Committee first proposed the virtualization of the Olympic movement, and now it has established an e-sports committee. This means that our understanding of traditional sports and e-sports are moving towards each other and are beginning to merge. The purpose is to enable more young people or enthusiasts to enter the Olympic family.

;

;We are now discussing how e-sports can enter this comprehensive sports meeting. The Hangzhou Asian Games treats it as an event alongside traditional sports. Other comprehensive sports games, such as the Commonwealth Games, South American Games or African Games, take another approach, which is to juxtapose e-sports as a business format with traditional sports formats. Within the scope of a large sports meeting, there are two business situation. How to better integrate is also being discussed.

;

;“The nationwide system is still applicable”

;

;;Southern Weekend:;;Always There is a voice that although we have hosted the Asian Games and Olympic Games and are competitive for gold medals in most sports events, it seems that mass sports or the masses' enthusiasm for sports is still not enough. What do you think of this problem? ;

;

;;Wei Jizhong: ;;It is important to pay attention to the gold medal, but paying too much attention to the gold medal will lead to what we used to call "championshipism." If you fall into championshipism, sometimes it will have some negative effects, such as using any means to win the championship. Results are important, but they don't mean everything. ;

;

;We cannot ignore mass sports. Through hosting the Asian Games and Olympic Games, the public's understanding of sports has been continuously improved. For example, before we host the 2022 Beijing Winter Olympics, we proposed the initiative of hundreds of millions of people participating in winter sports, and it was basically realized before the Winter Olympics were held. This shows that people's awareness of sports is constantly improving, so their enthusiasm for participation is also high.

;

;The question is, how do we organize them well? Competitive sports and mass sports are two aspects, but these two aspects are interoperable. We implement this aspect: professional athletes in competitive sports emerge from the mass system; the improvement of professional sports will inevitably provide guidance to mass sports. So I think popularization and improvement become a matter of interaction.

;

;;Southern Weekend:;;You have a point, the national system is still ours in competitive sports The advantage lies in. Nowadays, the development of some major ball sports is encountering some difficulties. What do you think is the path to professionalization under the current environment? ;

;

;;Wei Jizhong:;;The nationwide system is applicable to both competitive sports and mass sports. In fact, this nationwide system and centralized training of elites are also found in other countries. This is a professional sport, and the Olympic movement gradually transitions from amateurism to professionalism, and finally accepts a certain degree of professionalism. ;

;

;The basic path is mass, professional and professional. From professionalism to professionalism, there is the issue of commercialization. Regarding the issue of commercialization, I always remember what Chairman Samaranch told me during his lifetime: Sports must not be controlled by business, but sports can make use of business. Therefore, some of our projects are now developed on a market-oriented path, but they also need good support from the government. The nationwide system is still applicable. The question is, how to embody the nationwide system? Methods and methods may need to be reformed or improved.

;

;“I can’t decide, and I don’t participate in the decision”

;

;;Southern Weekend:;;You have done a lot of constructive work for the Chinese sports world. There are now some controversies outside, such as intervening in the appointment of the Chinese women's volleyball coach and the Chinese table tennis coach. How do you respond to these controversial issues? ;

;

;;Wei Jizhong:;;I have been engaged in sports for more than 60 years, but from my point of view, I have always been an executor. I am not a sports person. leader of. There were some misunderstandings on the Internet in the past, thinking that I can decide everything. No, I can't decide, and I don't participate in the decision. The entire selection of athletes and coaches is decided by professionals and government sports leadership agencies. I only carry out the tasks given to me or accept the instructions from my superiors, so I would like to use this opportunity to clarify that I It cannot decide on the volleyball coach, nor will it interfere with table tennis. ;

;

;I don’t have that much ability, nor do I have that much power to say that I decide all this and intervene in these decisions. I think this is (because) everyone doesn’t understand (the situation) well. Of course, some of my opinions may be wrong, and I accept everyone's criticism, but I absolutely cannot decide anything.

;

;;Southern Weekend:;;Since graduating from university in 1958, we have been working hard for decades The front line of sports has not yet retired. Where does your passion for sports come from? ;

;

;;Wei Jizhong: ;;Sports is mainly my interest and hobby. Although I am 87 years old, at the Hangzhou Asian Games, I still have to start from 7 in the morning Work until 10pm. Although I am retired, I should still use my spare energy when needed. It’s not that I must do something else, but once the country or some international sports organizations have such a need, I will try my best to do it within my ability, because sports are related to people’s health, national spirit and the masses. A public welfare undertaking that attracts attention. ;

;

;;Southern Weekend:;;In the past two years, domestic sports projects and personnel Management is becoming increasingly tighter. What major changes have you observed in the entire domestic sports environment? How to deal with these changes? ;

;

;;Wei Jizhong: ;;We are now in a stage of alternation between the old and the new. In this period of alternation between old and new, there needs to be a certain running-in period. ;

;

;I think from the perspective of the (sports) management, it may be in a running-in period. It is natural for some problems of one kind or another to occur during the running-in period. Precisely because of the running-in period, it is natural that the public will have different views on these issues. Some of the opinions of the masses may be relatively accurate, while others may be less accurate due to poor information.

;

;The replacement of athletes and coaches is a process. This process needs to be adjusted and gradually improved. Therefore, on the one hand, we must shorten this process as much as possible; on the other hand, we must also admit that there is such a process. From the management to the masses, we work together to make this process smoother.

; Wed, 04 Oct 2023 09:25:03 +0800 为什么要学英语？http://www.infzm.com/contents/258046
;;2023-10-04 08:00:00;
;

;In a recent interview, Ren Zhengfei mentioned his views on English learning. He said: "Learning in rural areas I understand that English is difficult, but if you put it through for a while, you will get through it, right? Maybe your oral expression is not that good, but you can do it if you have the ability to recognize words." This statement is quite pertinent to some of the popular opinions in the market. .

;

;It must be stated that whether a subject is useful to an individual's daily life cannot be used as a criterion for whether to enter a school for students to study. When it comes to the usefulness of daily life, how useful are physics, chemistry, history, and geography? It is enough to be able to calculate accounts and write in the third grade of primary school. Comparatively speaking, with the improvement of public education and the expansion of international exchanges, English has become more and more closely integrated with daily life: English is used when looking up certain knowledge and technologies, reading product manuals, and traveling abroad.

;

;Wikipedia information shows that as of March 25, 2020, W3Techs predicts that among the percentage of languages ​​used by the top one million Internet websites, English accounts for 59.3%. Chinese is 1.3%. Being more familiar with English is very useful for a person to increase his knowledge.

;

;From a national level, to a large extent, Chinese people learn foreign languages ​​to learn advanced foreign technologies.

;

;Any teaching is a pyramid-shaped screening system. China has a huge sports school system, which begins to discover and transport talents for sports from the elementary school level. This is the basis for Chinese athletes to win trophies in various competitions. Similarly, only if everyone starts learning addition and subtraction from the first grade, and then learns Newton's three laws in junior middle school, conservation of momentum, and the law of conservation of mechanical energy in high school, then there will be one in a hundred thousand or one in a million Mathematical Olympiad champions and Nobel laureates. Winner of the Bell Prize in Physics.

;

;The same is true for English. Only by starting to learn it in elementary school and taking English exams in college can we select the most cutting-edge people who are proficient in English and can engage in various researches.

;

;Some people say that you should learn English wherever necessary. Top talents can just learn English well. However, in elementary school, middle school and high school, no one could predict what would happen later. If the school system gives a signal that English is not important, and the college entrance examination succumbs to this trend and reduces the proportion of English, it will inevitably affect high school students’ attitude and enthusiasm for English learning. If high school students generally have poor English foundation, it will inevitably affect the overall English level of undergraduate students.

;

;In some schools, some subjects for undergraduate students are taught in English, which is conducive to improving students' professional English level and thus helping to keep up with the international advanced level. For example, if a Chinese scholar publishes an academic paper in a foreign journal, the most common language is English. During the publication process, foreign peer experts review the manuscript and give their opinions. Publication is a kind of recognition. This will help Chinese scholars in this field develop in the right technical direction. In fact, this is a process of technological diffusion.

;

;But if students generally have poor English after graduating from high school, English teaching will not be possible, and the possibility of publishing English papers abroad will become smaller.

;

;Moreover, technology diffusion does not only occur at the "high level" such as publishing papers and participating in international seminars. Technology diffusion and exchanges occur in all fields and levels of production. In many cases, such as The scenes we imagine are more down-to-earth and ordinary.

;

;During this period, generative AI has become popular. The United States is leading in this area, and China is also accelerating to catch up. If you want to use foreign generative AI, you need language skills from network settings, registration, writing prompts, and learning skills. For example, when it comes to AI-generated images and videos, a graphics, home decoration, and poster designer who is proficient in English can do it faster than a designer who lacks language skills. The latter will not even come into contact with this new thing because the language is too difficult. This can give the former a lead of half a year, a year, or even a few years, which will win customers and eventually the advantage will be solidified.

;

;For another example, if a small business owner who makes handicrafts can frequently visit foreign technology exchange websites, he will be able to discover many wonderful ideas. Sometimes technology diffusion is just a matter of "taking a look." However, if he does not have a basic knowledge of English, he will not go to these websites at all. He has neither the ability to find these websites nor the consciousness to do it.

;

;A very important reason why some people advocate learning less English or lowering English scores is that they think English is unfair to rural children. However, the paper "Research on the LDFA Method and Its Application in Project Function Difference Analysis", based on the data of the National Education Examination Center, used a completely random sampling method to extract the English test scores of 2,500 people, and found that urban and rural areas have higher college entrance examination English scores. There is no significant difference, even in rural areas it is 0.45 points higher.

;

;This is unexpected, but it is reasonable. In fact, many studies have found that there is no need for English, especially test-oriented English. Language learning is nothing more than reading more, listening more, and memorizing more. Practice makes perfect. In the era of widespread smartphones, the cost of an English-speaking environment is very low.

;

;Therefore, no matter from the perspective of the meaning of individual life, the progress of national technology, or the fairness of urban and rural education, English learning should not be underestimated, so that our children can be exposed to and discover the larger world. It can broaden your horizons and improve your knowledge and skills in professional fields when you grow up. This will remain true at least for quite some time to come.

;
